title: How to Change a Dremel Bit

steps.title: Turn off and disconnect your Dremel from the power source.
steps.content: Turn off and disconnect your Dremel from the power source. Unplug your Dremel tool from the outlet if you have a model with a cord. Take out the battery if you have a cordless model. [1] X Research source You should always do this first before working on any kind of power tool to make sure that you don’t accidentally turn it on. This will help prevent accidental injuries or damage to the tool.

steps.title: Press down and hold the button on the side of the Dremel near the chuck nut.
steps.content: Press down and hold the button on the side of the Dremel near the chuck nut. The chuck nut is the outer metal part at the tip of the Dremel that holds the bit. Look for a small button on the side of the Dremel near the chuck nut and hold it down. [2] X Research source This button is a security lock that will allow you to loosen the chuck nut so you can replace the bit. It keeps the bit from just twisting freely. [3] X Expert Source Jacob Pischer Home Improvement Specialist Expert Interview. 4 September 2020.

steps.title: Use a wrench to turn the chuck nut counterclockwise to loosen it.
steps.content: Use a wrench to turn the chuck nut counterclockwise to loosen it. Dremel tools come with a small wrench that fits the chuck nut perfectly, so it's best to use this. [4] X Expert Source Jacob Pischer Home Improvement Specialist Expert Interview. 4 September 2020. However, you can use any other wrench that fits if you have lost the wrench that came with your Dremel. [5] X Research source You can just loosen the chuck nut with the wrench and use your fingers to unscrew it until you can pull the bit out.

steps.title: Remove the bit or head from the collet.
steps.content: Remove the bit or head from the collet. The collet is the small metal part inside the chuck nut that actually holds the bit. Slide out whatever bit or head is attached to the Dremel currently and set it aside somewhere where you won’t lose it. [6] X Research source You can use all kinds of different bits with a Dremel tool for cutting, grinding, sanding, polishing, and other functions.

steps.title: Place the new bit you want to use in the collet.
steps.content: Place the new bit you want to use in the collet. Loosen or tighten the chuck nut with your fingers to adjust the collet to the size of the new bit you want to put in. Slide in the new bit or head. [7] X Research source Collets come in different sizes; not all collets can hold all sizes of bits. If the bit you want to use is too big or small for the collet in your Dremel tool, then you will need to replace the collet.

steps.title: Tighten the chuck nut with a wrench to secure the new bit in place.
steps.content: Tighten the chuck nut with a wrench to secure the new bit in place. Tighten the chuck nut with the Dremel tool wrench or whatever wrench you used to loosen the chuck nut. Your Dremel tool is now ready to use with the new bit. [8] X Research source Changing a Dremel bit is similar to changing any other drill bit . The way you release the chuck nut and loosen the collet may vary from tool to tool, but the general concept is the same.

steps.title: Purchase a Dremel collet and nut kit.
steps.content: Purchase a Dremel collet and nut kit. There are various kits available with different sizes of collets and replacement chuck nuts. Get a kit with collets that work with the bits you want to use. [9] X Research source If you aren’t sure what sizes you will need, you can purchase a kit labeled “miscellaneous” and you should have a variety that will work for many different sizes of bits. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Turn off your Dremel and disconnect it from any power sources.
steps.content: Turn off your Dremel and disconnect it from any power sources. Take out the battery after you turn it off if you have a cordless model. Unplug your Dremel tool from the outlet if you have a model with a cord. [11] X Research source This is a general safety rule that you should apply when working on any kind of power tool! Disconnecting tools from power sources will help avoid accidental injuries or damage to the tools.

steps.title: Hold down the button and loosen the chuck nut with a wrench.
steps.content: Hold down the button and loosen the chuck nut with a wrench. Press and hold the release button on the side of the Dremel near the chuck nut. Use the Dremel wrench, or another small wrench, to turn the chuck nut counterclockwise to loosen it. [12] X Research source You just need to get the chuck nut loose with a twist of the wrench so you can finish unscrewing it with your fingers.

steps.title: Screw off the chuck with your fingers.
steps.content: Screw off the chuck with your fingers. Keep turning the chuck nut counterclockwise with your fingers until it comes all the way off. Set it aside where you won’t lose it. [13] X Research source If you want to replace the chuck nut with a new nut that came in your kit, then you can discard the old nut at this time.

steps.title: Use your fingertips to slide out the collet.
steps.content: Use your fingertips to slide out the collet. The tip of the collet, the part that actually holds the bit, will now be exposed after you remove the chuck nut. Simply grab it between your fingers and slide it out, then set it aside. [14] X Research source The collet can just slip in and out, but if it has been sitting in the Dremel for a long time you might need to give it a little twist to get it to start sliding out.

steps.title: Slide in the new collet and screw the chuck nut back on.
steps.content: Slide in the new collet and screw the chuck nut back on. Select the size of collet that goes with the bit you want to use and slide it in. Screw the chuck nut on clockwise and tighten it with your wrench at the end. [15] X Research source Using different sizes of collets will allow you to adapt the bits you use to be more precise with your projects.
